text: To be a warrior is not a simple matter of wishing to be one. It is rather an endless struggle that will go on to the very last moment of our lives. Nobody is born a warrior, in exactly the same way that nobody is born an average man. We make ourselves into one or the other.
author: Natsume Sosek

text: Truth is so precious that she should always be attended by a bodyguard of lies.
author: Winston Churchill

text: I thought to myself with what means, with what deceptions, with how many varied arts, with what industry a man sharpens his wits to deceive another, and through these variations the world is made more beautiful.
author: Francesco Vettori

text: The infliction of cruelty with a good conscience is a delight to moralists–that is why they invented hell.
author: Bertrand Russell

text: Mind, n. A mysterious form of matter secreted by the brain. Its chief activity consists in the endeavor to ascertain its own nature, the futility of the attempt being due to the fact that is has nothing but itself to know itself with.
author: Ambrose Bierce

text: It is difficult to free fools from the chains they revere.
author: Voltaire

text: Better a diamond with a flaw than a pebble without.
author: Confucius

text: To live is not to breathe but to act. It is to make use of our organs, our senses, our faculties, of all the parts of ourselves which give us the sentiment of our existence. The man who has lived the most is not he who has counted the most years but he who has most felt life.
author: Jean-Jacques Rousseau

text: If we lie to the government, it’s a felony, but if they lie to us it’s politics.
author: Huey Freeman

text: Fear of a name increases fear of the thing itself.
author: J.K. Rowling

text: The suppression of uncomfortable ideas may be common in religion and politics, but it is not the path to knowledge.
author: Carl Sagan

text: A woman may very well form a friendship with a man, but for this to endure, it must be assisted by a little physical antipathy.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

text: If the natural tendencies of mankind are so bad that it is not safe to permit people to be free, how is it that the tendencies of these organizers are always good? Do not the legislators and their appointed agents also belong to the human race? Or do they believe that they themselves are made of a finer clay than the rest of mankind?
author: Frédéric Bastiat

text: Propaganda does not deceive people; it merely helps them to deceive themselves.
author: Eric Hoffer

text: Turning conscience into a liability is a fundamental goal of all power systems.
author: Stefan Molyneux

text: What does seventy million years mean to beings who live only one-millionth as long? We are like butterflies who flutter for a day and think it is forever.
author: Carl Sagan

text: A leader is best when people barely know that he exists, not so good when people obey and acclaim him, worst when they despise him. Fail to honor people, they fail to honor you. But of a good leader, who talks little, when his work is done, his aims fulfilled, they will all say: We did this ourselves.
author: Lao Tzu

text: Not every truth is the better for showing its face unveiled.
author: Pindar

text: By three methods we may learn wisdom: First, by reflection, which is noblest; Second, by imitation, which is easiest; And third by experience, which is the bitterest.
author: Confucius

text: Words often betray their own purpose, obscuring the very thoughts they are designed to express.
author: Francis Bacon

text: The test of a first-rate intelligence is the ability to hold two opposed ideas in mind at the same time and still retain the ability to function.
author: F. Scott Fitzgerald

text: When we think back on our past sensations or feelings, our thought is a faithful mirror that copies its objects truly; but it does so in colors that are fainter and more washed-out than those in which our original perceptions were clothed.
author: David Hume

text: Only silly folk identify creative originality with the extraordinary and fanciful; others recognize that its measure lies in putting everyday things to uses which had not occurred to others. The operation is novel, not the materials out of which it is constructed.
author: John Dewey

text: I was really too honest a man to be a politician and live.
author: Socrates

text: A man can rationalize anything if he thinks about it long enough.
author: Anonymous

text: Only two things are infinite, the universe and the human stupidity, and I am not too sure about the former
author: Albert Einstein

text: Being able to break security doesnt make you a hacker anymore than being able to hotwire cars makes you an automotive engineer.
author: Eric Raymond

text: Simplicity is the ultimate sophistication.
author: Leonardo da Vinci

text: Do everything you can to make it around the system, over the system, or in the system.
author: Tupac Shakur

text: Television is about watching a life instead of having one.
author: Beth Mazur

text: If you ask the government for permission to protest it, you deserve to be told no.
author: Jim Lesczynski

text: It is easy in the world to live after the world’s opinion; it is easy in solitude to live after our own; but the great man is he who in the midst of the crowd keeps with perfect sweetness the independence of solitude.
author: Ralph Emerson

text: The brain is a wonderful organ; it starts working the moment you get up in the morning and does not stop until you get into the office.
author: Robert Frost

text: When you meet a swordsman, draw your sword. Do not recite poetry to one who is not a poet.
author: Robert Greene

text: All our knowledge merely helps us to die a more painful death than animals that know nothing.
author: Maurice Maeterlinck

text: Democracy is being allowed to vote for the candidate you dislike least.
author: Robert Byrne

text: Politics is the gentle art of getting votes from the poor and campaign funds from the rich, by promising to protect each from the other.
author: Oscar Ameringer

text: The big thieves hang the little ones.
author: Czech Proverb

text: That government is best which governs least.
author: Thomas Jefferson

text: Nerds just don't happen to dress informally. They do it too consistently. Consciously or not, they dress informally as prophylactic measure against stupidity.
author: Paul Graham

text: Give a man a 0day and he'll have access for a day, teach a man to phish and he'll have access for life.
author: the grugq

text: We are so vain that we even care for the opinion of those we don't care for.
author: Marie von Ebner-Eschenbach

text: The world is a dangerous place... not because of those who do evil, but because of those who look on and do nothing.
author: Mr. Robot

text: A perfect plan doesn't mean having everything go within expectations. A perfect plan is achieved when it has the plasticity needed to flexibly deal with troubles.
author: Makishima Shougo

text: No matter what side of the argument you are on, you always find people on your side that you wish were on the other.
author: Thomas Berger

text: Everyone wants to live at the expense of the state. They forget that the state lives at the expense of everyone.
author: Frédéric Bastiat

text: Be curious. Read widely. Try new things. What people call intelligence just boils down to curiosity.
author: Aaron Swartz

text: If there is a problem you can't solve, then there is an easier problem you can solve: find it.
author: George Pólya

text: You can either be informed and your own rulers, or you can be ignorant and have someone else, who is not ignorant, rule over you.
author: Julian Assange

text: Do I not destroy my enemies when I make them my friends?
author: Abraham Lincoln

text: It is incumbent on every generation to pay its own debts as it goes. A principle which if acted on would save one-half the wars of the world.
author: Thomas Jefferson

text: Bodily decay is gloomy in prospect, but of all human contemplations the most abhorrent is body without mind.
author: Thomas Jefferson

text: There’s no freedom quite like the freedom of being constantly underestimated.
author: Scott Lynch

text: I don't care if I pass your test, I don't care if I follow your rules. If you can cheat, so can I. I won't let you beat me unfairly - I'll beat you unfairly first.
author: Ender Wiggin

text: Do not envy those who seem to be naturally gifted; it is often a curse, as such types rarely learn the value of diligence and focus, and they pay for this later in life.
author: Robert Greene

text: Arguing that you don’t care about the right to privacy because you have nothing to hide is no different than saying you don’t care about free speech because you have nothing to say.
author: Edward Snowden

text: If you want to go quickly, go alone. If you want to go far, go together.
author: African Proverb

text: Propaganda is to a democracy what the bludgeon is to a totalitarian state.
author: Noam Chomsky

text: I’ve never found it hard to hack most people. If you listen to them, watch them, their vulnerabilities are like a neon sign screwed into their heads.
author: Elliot Alderson

text: Your mind is programmable – if you’re not programming your mind, someone else will program it for you.
author: Jeremy Hammond

text: If a machine is expected to be infallible, it cannot also be intelligent.
author: Alan Turing

text: Innovation is serendipity, so you don't know what people will make.
author: Tim Berners-Lee

text: If all mankind minus one were of one opinion, mankind would be no more justified in silencing that one person than he, if he had the power, would be justified in silencing mankind.
author: John Stuart Mill

text: You can jail a Revolutionary, but you can't jail the Revolution.
author: Huey Newton
